description: Learned borrowing from Latin bacillus (“little staff, wand”), diminutive of baculum (“stick, staff, walking stick”).

entries.meaning: Any of various rod-shaped, spore-forming aerobic bacteria in the genus Bacillus, some of which cause disease.
examples: 'This again,' said the Bacteriologist, slipping a glass slide under the microscope, 'is a preparation of the celebrated Bacillus of cholera - the cholera germ.'

entries.meaning: (figurative, by extension) Something which spreads like bacterial infection.
examples: The “bacillus of boom or depression,” he wrote, travels freely “from country to country.”
